natural problem: Find all solutions to the inequality \[\frac{x^2}{(x-3)^2} \ge 0.\](Give your answer in interval notation.)
natural solution: As the quotient of two perfect squares, the left-hand side is always nonnegative when it is defined. The left-hand side is defined whenever $x \neq 3,$ so the solution set is $\boxed{ (-\infty, 3) \cup (3, \infty) }.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "x \<in> {x. x \<le> 3} \<union> {x. x > 3} \<longleftrightarrow> x powr 2 / (x - 3) powr 2 \<ge> 0"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find all solutions to the inequality \[\frac{x^2}{(x-3)^2} \ge 0.\](Give your answer in interval notation.) The final Answer is  (-\infty, 3) \cup (3, \infty) 
 ### Proof
 As the quotient of two perfect squares, the left-hand side is always nonnegative when it is defined. The left-hand side is defined whenever $x \neq 3,$ so the solution set is $\boxed{ (-\infty, 3) \cup (3, \infty) }.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "x \<in> {x. x \<le> 3} \<union> {x. x > 3} \<longleftrightarrow> x powr 2 / (x - 3) powr 2 \<ge> 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: The problem asks to prove that for any real number $x$, $x$ is either less than or equal to 3, or greater than 3 if and only if the value of the expression $\frac{x^2}{(x-3)^2}$ is greater than or equal to zero.

shows  "((x powr 2) / ((x - 3) powr 2)) \<ge> 0 \<longleftrightarrow> (x < 3 \<or> x > 3)"
